With the difference that Skyrim actually is good.An example: You build your building in a minute. Then you upgrade it in an hour. Then you upgrade it in I think three or six hours. Then in 24 hours. And that is only if you have enough people.Wait, what? Yes, you need free people to upgrade buildings. Which you get - surprise - by building and upgrading certain buildings. If you have partial people, the upgrade takes longer.Then there is science, which works pretty well so far, except everything takes ages. The first science thing is done in an hour. Then if you upgrade your buildings science goes faster, but you can't upgrade enough in a reasonable time to make it worthwhile.The "innovative" system that makes you not grinding is - you guess it - resources trickle at a ridiculous small rate (since you'd need to upgrade buildings to get more resources) while you're offline. You can use them then to upgrade buildings and build armies. At which point you probably rather want to play through Ride to Hell: Retribution, Secret of the Magic Crystals, Rambo, Kane & Lynch 2 or even E.T. 2600 because you have more fun there.EDIT: Just found an official screenshot that demonstrates how long this game takes. 												Shameless pay-to-win.This is a "time management" game. You acquire basic resources over time, use them to make buildings and troops that allow you to get and store more resources, build more buildings, and continue the cycle. It has the typical limits to building construction, and a research system that is required to unlock everything from adding other users to your contacts list to building defenses to hiring troops.Black gems are purchased for real money. This is where things get ugly. You can technically acquire black gems through playing, but if you're really lucky you might earn 1 or 2 per day. Research and building upgrades typically require black gems for the higher tiers. Hero equipment and general buffs can only be purchased with black gems. The cheapest thing you can buy for black gems costs 10 of them, and prices quickly escalate to the hundreds, thousands, and even hundreds of thousands of black gems. This means that you're required to spend thousands of real dollars if you want to do well. Many, if not most, of the quests are simply to buy a buff for black gems, and have a time limit that will cause you to fail the quest (and some of the achievements) if you don't pay real money immediately.Quests and other actions are not explained well, so players have to guess what most actions do, and what different values mean.There isn't any action in the game. There are attacks, but they're simply calculations and RNG that happens behind the scenes. You never see a battle.There aren't many bugs, but there are some game-breaking bugs. For example, my hero was killed on a mission, and didn't become available to respawn in the place where he was supposed to. I tried hiring a new hero to replace him, but couldn't because the game said I already had a hero, so I became permanently stuck without a hero.If a player who is stronger than you decides to attack you, they can destroy almost everything you have, and leave you unable to retaliate. You can normally only attack players who are the same level as you, but paid buffs can allow you to attack any other player. This means that days or even months of effort will be destroyed any time a P2W player decides that it would be amusing to destroy a non-P2W player. This can also undo any progress you've made with the help of the extremely overpriced DLCs.The graphics are very plain. They're not great, but not bad either.There isn't much audio, and what little there is gets repetitive very quickly. Luckily, you can mute it.If you leave don't play for 4 days, your resource production and research will stop, and your units will begin leaving. If you go for too long without playing (they don't state how long) then your account is deleted. You can pay to prevent your account from being deleted for some time, but that means that you're paying to not play this game.On a positive note, there is an official wiki, which is linked to in-game. Unfortunately, the English version is very lacking.

												So this is an MMO stratedgy game: you make choices about how your fantasy kingdom developes and expands by setting research and production goals.  Then you construct armies that fight NCP and player armies automatically.  You try to expand your territories until you are in a state of constant war with your neighbors, who did the same thing but maybe with a different stratedgy.This isn't an terrible game of this type, but there were much, much better games of this type, with far more to do, before the whole "F2P; P2W" trend started.  I've played games of this type that let you do more things, more often, earlier in your cities developement (because they weren't hoping you would pay to speed things up) as well as games that just had way more you could do (such as games that let march heroes around your territory fighting little monsters while your were waiting on research, or games that had big books of spells and such you could cast).  Ultimately. this game is ok, but there are deeper, more invovled games of the same type you could play for free that would be more fun.  There doesn't seem to be a lot of strategic diversity--its not like you can focus on magic, espionage, your military, or your economy to create a unque play style--everyone is going to be be playing more or less the same way.  If you like the general concept of this game, google around for a bit and you'll probably find something you'd enjoy more.

												TL;DR : Nice Concept, Poor Execution. No Sound, Microtransactions. Quite fun to play as a break. 7/10FULL REVIEW.This game is interesting to say the least, but somewhat lacking in it's delivery.Let's start with me turning the game on, quick download, quick start up, Simple graphics, but not terrible. However, no sound.I first thought it was a bug or something but after checking a few times, this game dosent have sound files. At all.This game looks and sort of plays like a Facebook game, but it is more easily compared to Travian, in which you create homes, on a hexagonal area, build up resources and expand to different areas. At time of writing i have only played about an hour.The game is ported from a mobile game (as clear in some text documents) but they have changed the interface to make it more PC gamer friendly, and I commend them for that. A nice simple tutorial quest system that goes on for about 20 minutes before you were considered to be in charge of what you were doing, which is nice. The combat system is good at a glance, simple RTS but on a longer timescale. Creating troops and having them fight on a different area. It reminds me of the Total War series, but backwards. You manage a city and what buildings appear, but then have a larger map view to move armies around a hexagonal area. These hexagons have different boosts to different units and make an intresting combat system.Like all facebook games it seems plagued with micro-transactions. Which in my opinion are not an issue. They are not predominant on the screen and you have to go through several clicking to speed up a process. It's there, but not directly advertised. Besides, a free to play game has to make money somehow.As I sit here waiting for my population to rise so I can build more buildings to gather more resources, I am pulled in by a strange charm to this game. It feels a bit like alot of other games, but has a much better combat and fighting system. I can only reccommend you at least try this game, just to see if it intrests you.To see more Free-To-Play reviews visit my profile and check out my other reviews.www.twitter.com/Xelforce

Name: My LandsVariations: My Lands: Black Gem HuntingDeveloper: Elyland LLC, Gravvit LLCDate: 2010Category: MMOGenre: BBMMORTSOrientation: MultiplayerPopulation: CrowdedPerspective: 2.5D - Isometric - (Static)Timeflow: Background Real-Time, PersistentSkills: Brain + Endurance + ResponsibilitySetting: FantasyStyle: -Tags: No Campaign, No Story, Open World, RPG ElementsModel: F2P-P2WContent: P2W DLC, Microtransactions, SubscriptionPlatforms: PC, BrowserReview: Fantasy browser-based MMORTS, proclaimed by its russian developers to be "the very first browser MMOG with the possibility to withdraw money gained in the course of the game to players' own e-purses". Could be true, but I doubt you can actually do this, as the game is so P2W that to achieve anything you have to pay, a lot. What's the profit then.	Feauturing 4 absolutely same races (with different pictures), typical browser-based gameplay with battle reports only, premium currency 'Black Gems' which can make ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING in the game harder/better/faster/stronger, heroes with unique artefacts and sets (for Black Gems only).	The biggest fail imo: when Steam version was launched (4 years after release), they didn't actually transfer or merge anything. Just 2 separate Steam servers were created with no possibility to even transfer existing account from browser version to Steam. Of course dedicated people who played this game for years and invested a lot of money didn't want to start again with new empty accounts. Also, (hilarious but true!!) Steam servers and browser servers run different version of the game, with Steam being several patches behind!!! It even lacks some important content as I've heard. So obviously, Steam version, as some smart guy said, is literally 'playing with itself', while browser version (if to trust developers) still keeps several thousands active accounts. Yeah, the game was popular when just released. Too bad I didn't play it back then, people say it wasn't P2W yet, and was pretty damn fun.	Abusive monetization starts with the very first quest and keeps getting harder and harder, you see this 'Black Gems required' everywhere. Yeah you can actually mine those in mystical 'Saline Lakes' in very very lategame, but from what I heard they are extremely hard to keep control of. Or you can buy BG on auction for tons of gold.	Can't tell anything about strategic (military) depth as I didn't play it that long. What I have seen is pretty big amount of various buildings (as for browser game), 6 resources, 8 units (again, same for all races, with different pictures) and sheet-ton of artifacts and sets for heroes to purchase.	Tell you a story. I spent good time once (not so long ago) searching for a good quality BBMMORTS. Most of that time went into filtering these countless 'facebook strategy' clones for 10 y.o kids, reetardedly simple and bright and with same awful money-sucking monetization. And my guess is, these genre just outlived itself. NOTHING of OGame-quality (or at least close to) was found. Just Travian, which I won't play because I hate its comical-style. And this one, My Lands.	Not sure what this game was before, as it was pretty popular (and not only in Russia). But right now it's just a money-sucking machine. And not captivating at all. Perhaps focused at draining funds from existing playerbase. Just don't play it. 												This game makes a nice break to the day and doesn't require heavy micromanagement.  There is no endless clicking of buildings to collect resources like other games; resources automatically collect in your warehouses.  I prefer that much more than other RTS games where you have to log in exactly when buildings are full to manually collect resources.  While the game is light on the micromanaging, it is not light on strategy.  You need to think and plan in advance to outsmart other players that want what you've got and are scheming how to take it.   You might find yourself staying up scouring the internet for strategies and guides, and each one leaves you with multitudes of ways to achieve your goals, but not all of the ways will be best for your race, hero, and play style.  The best thing I enjoy though is the hero system.  Each hero class is unique and customizable at higher levels.  The NPC monster ruins that pop up provide an addicting hunt and kill component, and if you are good enough, eventually you will find and conquer ruins with monster bosses which can reward you with hoards of loot.

												This is a barely-translated pay2win browser game with a 48 hour tutorial. I don't mean the tutorial is available at all times, I mean it literally takes that long to build and research what you need to complete the tutorial, assuming you check in at the appropriate times (queueing research items is for premium players only). The only reason this could be considered a Real Time Strategy game is because there are no turns. The only obvious Steam integration is the achievements; there is no overlay and I imagine it uses the same servers as its browser counterpart. There is no fullscreen, graphics and animations are minimal, and the music manages to be forgettable and annoying at the same time. The game's entire plot revolves around fighting over the in-game currency, which is also mentioned in the title (black gems). The developers have only put in the bare minimum amount of effort needed to keep this scam afloat; the mountain of fake user reviews have better spelling than the game itself.Literally the only positive things about this "game" are that it does everything in its power to keep you from actually playing it, and that it serves as a vile example of how not to make a game.

Posted: October 24, 2014
												Though I am a fan of this genre I was disappointed with My Lands. A large part of this is simply because My Lands doesn't belong on steam where its effectively tied to a single computer. You need the ability to connect from a browser and your mobile devices, but according to a post from the Devs in the google play store the steam version is on a different server so it cannot be accessed vie the web or mobile devices. This could have been mitigated if it had a better queuing system, but you need to pay Black Gems to get any sort of queues, and there is no building queue. You start with a small number of Black Gems and they can be earned within the game by destroying ruins and harvesting the proper locations, but unless you are really patient there simply aren't enough of them without paying money. Since the game is already free on the web, I would preferred to have the steam version cost money but include the premium benefits and share the same servers as the browser version.My other complaints are that everything takes longer in My Lands than in similar games and the interface could use some improvements. This type of game relies on an active player base but the build time ramps up so quickly that new players don't have time to get hooked. As for the interface there is no sound, scouting is instant but the information isn't saved anywhere, and you can't see at a glance where you explored or attacked or even who is a legal target.The game DOES have potential and I may continue playing the browser version. The different races are interesting, you have a high level of control over your city, the tutorial quests are helpful and most importantly it is entirely up to you when you open yourself to PVP. These are all strong benefits but are outweighed by the flaws. This is not a bad game, its just a bad _steam_ game. While you can successfully take a browser game and put it on steam, you need to make sizable changes for it to succeed.

While you can estimate 1,000 black gems to cost 15$, you cannot purchase in blocks of 1,000 gems. You must purchase 650 gems (10$) or 1500 gems (20$). This essentially means that in order to get a second hero you must pay 20$. I do not wish to even know what rank 3 will charge you.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Lots of negative reviews about this game, which I can understand some of the reasons, but completely disagree and think they've not played it long enough to give it a fair chance.The game is fairly slow at the start. The quests guide you through the very basics and then you basically take your own route.Black Gems are the "special" resource in the game. They allow you to buy buffs and get the best things. They can be bought for real money, or you can earn them in the game. At first, you won't earn many in the game unless you're very lucky. But by the time you've built up to attack ruins, which takes about a week or so, you can bring in several a day and eventually working up to thousands a day. They can also be bought with gold in the game which is a standard resource.The ranking system stops the top players attacking the smallest ones, so you're safe to start with. There are 5 ranks and you can only attack people of the same rank or above what you are. The battles are just a calculation, but the beauty of this game is calculating all the buffs you have vs your enemy to be successful. Finding ways to outsmart people is the joy of this game.You have to pay a salary to your army, so there's a balance between having a big army and being able to manage the salary.All in all, I've played lots of online games and never found anything that I enjoy as much as this game. Yes, it is slow to start with and takes a lot of time to build up. You can substitute that for money, but I know many people who have succeded in this game without paying a penny

												This review is about my experience with My Lands: Black Gem Hunting. I spent many hours on this game so I could tell you just about everything about it but I will shorten it to how I feel about the game overall. First off, I do not like RTS games at all. I had played a few online browser and app RTS games in the past such as Travian, Combat Grounds, and Game of War (btw do not ever play GoW). They were fun sometimes but got old after awhile and once you start to become powerful you always get shot down by higher ranked people in clans/guilds who paid thousands of real world money to get to their level. I have also played the Stronghold series and do not enjoy those games. My Lands was sort of an exception to my experience with RTS games. I started playing this game because I got a free 6 month premium account and figured, why not give it a try? Plus I read you can make money playing the game. Sweet! In the beginning, I really did not know what I was doing but I thought it was kinda fun. The more I started to play and learn about the game, I realised just how much strategy and meticulous, critical planning the game requires. This discovery made the game more intriguing and enjoyable. Once I found an English speaking clan (lots of Russians play, i.e. the majority) I was set. I was a free to play player for a long time and I had NO issues with being F2P. I  was mostly PvE on the Age of Abundance server but I was PvP on occasion, and more so on the other server. Of course if I was super rich the game would be easier, but I learned through reading the My Lands encyclopedia, forums, and from my clan members how to gain power and defend myself from all attacks. The only con I can say about this game is that it requires you to be on every single day. I would say no less than 2-3 separate times EACH day. It is an RTS after all.If you miss a day several things can happen: 1. You get attacked2. You miss a monster ruin (which are crucial to gaining resources and power)3. You lose an auction4. Your clan needed your help but you were afk5. Your mine gets stolen6. If it's your 7th or 14th consecutive missed day (can't remember which) your city gates open, people leave your villages (no resources gathered), then they leave your cities.7. If you are gone a month your account(s) is/are deleted.I was loyal to this game and determined to make money playing it. I was on everyday for months having fun every time I played. That is why my hours are so high. Most of it was not idling. Unfortunately, the place where I was staying had terrible internet which would not allow me to access Steam 90% of the time. I missed some weeks and got attacked but I was still strong in the game and my clan supported me. Basically, it could have been worse... Now I've quit My Lands indefinitely because I just logged on and both of my accounts are gone.If you like RTS games, My Lands is fun. The graphics are nice. The UI is not hard to figure out. The devs added some fitting music after a few months. You can make money playing it by turning black gems collected into money. I believe it's 100 gems = $1.00. Apparently players have made over $2.5million playing the game. It takes a lot of time if you are F2P though. I earned $0.00 in my 650+ hours... I recommend it if you have the time.
